awd_titl_txt: CAS: Collaborative Research: New Hybrid Catalysts for Sustainable Cross-Coupling Reactions:  Using Atomic Layer Deposition to Immobilize and Enhance Molecular Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Chemicals like plastics and medicines are essential to modern life.  However, large-scale chemical production can require large amounts of energy and can create toxic waste.  Catalysts can reduce the energy needed to produce chemicals, reduce waste, and provide large cost savings for chemical manufacturers.  The goal of this project is to develop new catalysts to make specific chemical products while also reducing both energy usage and the creation of toxic waste. This research is developing advanced catalysts that are both selective and easily recovered for repeated use.  Further, these catalysts are being used in non-toxic and non-corrosive liquids, like water.  Thus, these catalysts make chemical production safer for workers and reduce hazards to surrounding communities and the environment. This research program is studying how to design these catalysts for use in chemical reactions that are otherwise difficult to achieve under less hazardous and energy efficient conditions.  This program pairs Dr. Aaron Vannucci at the University of South Carolina, an expert in chemical catalysis, with Dr. Mark Losego at the Georgia Institute of Technology, an expert in materials synthesis.  Ph.D. students funded by this project are being jointly trained in both fields. This exchange of skills is expanding the scientific training for students in both groups and will impact future students at both universities.  Dr. Vannucci is actively running outreach programs to train high school teachers in the chemical sciences.  Dr. Losego is directing a materials analysis facility run by and for undergraduate students.  These programs promote interest, education, and training in STEM fields at multiple levels. Skills exchanged during this project are being used to further enhance these hands-on STEM training programs. 

With joint funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research, Dr. Aaron Vannucci from the University of South Carolina and Dr. Mark Losego from the Georgia Institute of Technology are collaboratively developing knowledge about new hybrid catalysts that immobilize non-precious metal molecular catalysts on oxide nanoparticle supports with nano-scale metal oxide over-layers deposited via atomic layer deposition (ALD).  These molecular/heterogeneous catalysts have already shown excellent recyclability for Suzuki cross-coupling reactions via simple filtration and washing. Physicochemical studies are being conducted to understand not only the ability for ALD layers to physically stabilize the catalyst molecules on the particle surfaces but also the synergistic chemical interactions between the ALD metal oxide over-layer and molecular catalyst that lead to enhanced catalytic activity.  Specifically, the investigators are developing strategies using ALD processing and chemistry to control the local geometric and chemical environment around the active site to achieve difficult C(sp3)-C(sp3) and stereoconvergent coupling reactions relevant to medical research and drug discovery.  These hybrid catalysts adhere to many green chemistry principles including the utilization of non-noble metals, operation in non-corrosive, aqueous solvents, and ease in separation and recyclability.  This program also supports extended student and investigator exchanges at the collaborative institutions to cross-train the Ph.D. students in orthogonal scientific disciplines of chemical catalysis and vapor deposition processing.  These knowledge and skill sets are being institutionalized in each lab group and broadly impact current and future generations of students.  During these exchanges the visiting investigators are developing programs to further enhance existing outreach and training programs that support hands-on undergraduate education and high school teacher training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is a need for more sustainable chemical syntheses, specifically for fine chemicals such as pharmaceuticals, materials, and drug discovery. Increasing sustainability involves avoiding toxic solvents, the use of catalysts, and specifically the use of earth abundant metal catalysts. Using catalysts to promote chemical synthesis helps lower the energy required to perform the reactions and can help increase chemical product yields. The use of earth abundant metal catalysts not only avoids depleting rare, difficult to mine metals, but also offers less expensive chemical synthesis procedures. However, it is often difficult to control the reactivity of earth abundant metal catalysts, especially when using these catalysts in non-toxic “green” solvents such as water.

This research project set out to develop a catalytic system that utilized earth-abundant nickel catalysts for efficient chemical synthesis related to pharmaceutically relevant chemical reactions. We were able to achieve this goal by immobilizing molecular nickel catalysts to solid oxide supports. Our immobilization technique is akin to cementing a fence post into the ground. Catalysts are "cemented" to solid supports through a vapor deposition technique called Atomic Layer Deposition, or ALD. The ALD technique is widely used in the electronics and cell phone industry and here we uniquely apply it to our catalyst synthesis and design. Once cemented down, the nickel catalysts studied in this project were no longer free to move in solution to interact with each other. This lack of interaction stabilized the catalysts and led to achieving chemical bond forming reactions called cross-coupling. This reactivity was achieved in water solutions for the first time. Each nickel catalyst was able to synthesize thousands of chemical products and the catalysts were easily removed from reaction mixtures and reused for multiple reaction runs. The results of this project greatly increased the sustainability and “green chemistry’ of the targeted synthesis reactions and opened up a new design principle for future catalyst syntheses.

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2024
Modified by: Aaron K Vannucci

Images (1 of )
  • Catalysts bound to solid oxide supports exhibit longer lifetimes and more catalytic turnovers compared to molecular catalysts in solution.
    Organometallics 2019, 38, 2007-2014
    Copyrighted
    Aaron K Vannucci
    Catalyst Reactivity on Surface
  • After a catalyst is bound to a solid oxide support, additional oxide layers can be applied through a vapor deposition technique. These additional layers essentially "cement" the catalyst in place and prevent many common catalyst decomposition routes.
    Aaron Vannucci
    Public Domain
    Aaron K Vannucci
    3-D Cemented with ALD Catalyst
  • In solutions containing water, nickel catalysts often decompose into inactive forms. Preventing these common decomposition routes, and thus increasing the lifetime and usability of these catalysts, was the gain goal of this project
    Aaron Vannucci
    Public Domain
    Aaron K Vannucci
    Molecular Instability
